commit 11a85a244f51ab465cf6c8daef329be6a0b4d8e3
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-07-14 13:33:05 +0100

    Add Windows build scripting
    
    Build script for Windows, relying on as little as possible.
    
    Needed: MSYS2 latest
    Optional: Inno Setup 5.5
    
    Running the script generates a standalone .zip for people wanting to just
    stick MyPaint on a portable flash drive, and a .exe installer for people
    wanting to install MyPaint permanently.
    
    The mypaint-wXX-VERSION-setup.exe style installer output is more user
    friendly, and may already be good enough for distribution with our betas.
    After installation, you can still modify the app's Python files so it's
    still hackable. We deliberately don't rip out much of its Python (yet).
    
    The portable/standalone mypaint-wXX-VERSION.zip output is not very well
    behaved (it needs to write into its PREFIX, and it flashes a CMD.EXE window
    briefly), but it would work well for people who don't trust installers or
    want to do things themselves, or just want MyPaint on a flash stick.

23	30	README_WINDOWS.md

2	0	windows/mypaint-bin.cmd
16	0	windows/mypaint-standalone.cmd

4	0	windows/postinst.cmd

commit 657b2df3219c3231d6f36b7616372ea81ccd7835
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-07-03 17:18:28 +0100

    Optionally hide the cursor while painting
    
    There is now a setting in the application preferences to hide the cursor
    while drawing - i.e. while the pen is down. This can make using a tablet PC
    more pleasant.
    
    Closes mypaint/mypaint#356.
    
    Strings merge needed too, do that at freeze.

commit 5570f94a609bf036f8bb2cac072e2b86ddafa30b
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-07-08 01:17:04 +0100

    Win32: support build on MSYS2 using MSYS-scons
    
    Extend support to cover building for the native MINGW32 platform on MSYS2
    and letting it invoke the MSYS environment's scons.
    
    Drop requirement for using scons-local. It served its purpose,
    but we can use MSYS2's own tested scons now.

49	45	README_WINDOWS.md
13	6	SConstruct
1	1	brushlib
70	10	lib/SConscript

commit 866fe653a6a5a4c1a6bebc637ec519d99b78e316
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-07-07 14:03:48 +0100

    Build scripting: improve NumPy detection
    
    Improve auto-detection of the NumPy headers. Building for MSYS2's
    MINGW32 using its MSYS scons is unlikely to be possible due to path syntax
    differences between what the target's pkg-config returns and what MSYS's
    os.path.join() expects, but we can still make improvements:
    
    * Try the target Python executable first, in a subprocess,
    * Don't rely on having numpy installed in the build environment,
    * Allow the autoguesswork to be overridden with a build option.

1	0	SConstruct
52	10	lib/SConscript

commit f4a20ee10e2d7c203c7aed5433d8f335ce5f1b1b
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-07-04 21:18:37 +0100

    Add po/mypaint.pot, update po/SConscript & docs
    
    MyPaint itself is moving to the same translation model as
    libmypaint starting with the upcoming string freeze,
    i.e. developers introducing new strings should update
    the .pot file and all po/*.po after introducing a string change.
    Translators now just maintain their own .po file(s).
    
    po/SConscript: reflect evolving workflow, document.
    
    Update po/README.md, but omit any mentions of WebLate just yet.
    
    Submodule bump to catch similar updates there.
    
    Addresses mypaint/mypaint#348.
    
    .po files have not been updated yet - that will happen shortly.

commit 594f2e8bae8a7041c059b61fa106bf3c344e65fd
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-07-04 17:45:03 +0100

    brushmodifier: fix rare exception
    
    Occasionally the brush colour that brushmanager tries to restore when the
    user changes brush can be None. What happens is dictated by a combination
    of the restore_color setting of both the pre- and post-change brushes, and
    the user's settings (devbrushes specifically, I *think*).
    
    It can be triggered semi-reproduceably in _at_application_start too, with
    files containing stroke-maps whose top stroke has triggering brush
    settings. But it still depends on the user settings.
    
    Anyway, don't try to unpack None.
    
    Fixes mypaint/mypaint#354.

5	3	gui/brushmodifier.py
2	0	lib/brush.py

Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>

    i18n: fix failure to update .pot
    
    xgettext requires Python files' "-*- coding: utf-8 -*-" lines to be
    expressed exactly like that. Using "utf8", which works in Python itself,
    won't do.
    
    Closes mypaint/mypaint#361.

commit 8c1b97234726544de6c74e5ff3921bfa9e82eee8
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-07-02 22:31:43 +0100

    bg tile: deprecate old attr, introduce namespaced attr
    
    The old background_tile attribute name will be deprecated with 1.2.0.
    Introduce a namespaced mypaint:background-tile attr to replace this
    field. MyPaint will support reading the old name until 2.0.0,
    and will write it out in parallel with the new one until 1.3.0.

commit 38bc4b90c45c39b240a483f1ae5a47fcf56f8042
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-07-02 18:07:53 +0100

    Extend support for reading old strokemap
    
    Egg-on-face moment: I am a dope, and I can't read specification documents.
    Semver practice is to deprecate in one MINOR version, and retain support
    until the next MINOR version, not patch version.
    
    Reading the old strokemap attribute and file format is now due to be
    discontinued in v1.3.0, not v1.2.1. Oops.

commit 513e9e2bb35ab710395880b1dee6c916350998aa
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-07-02 01:29:52 +0100

    OpenRaster: save+load whether the frame is active
    
    Save a custom xsd:bool declaring whether the frame is on or off in an XML
    attribute in OpenRaster files and autosave oradirs. It's a distinct
    concept from image size, and shouldn't be confused with it.
    
    Update the frame-enabled state from the saved value when loading OpenRaster
    files or oradirs files. The default is no frame (infinite canvas).
    
    Closes mypaint/mypaint#18.

20	13	lib/document.py

commit f4fe249c13d2f0b3d15ec540b73da96b55bffa6e
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-07-02 01:26:25 +0100

    OpenRaster: use XML namespace for custom attrs
    
    Begin deprecating and phasing out old XML attribute names in a controlled
    fashion (see http://semver.org).
    
    * Attr mypaint_strokemap_v2 → mypaint:strokemap
      - We'll write a duplicate attr with the old name until v1.2.1 at least.
      - Reading the old strokemap attr name is supported until v2.0.0.
    * Attr mypaint_unsaved_painting_time → mypaint:unsaved-painting-time
      - Only used for autosaves, not part of any "public API", in semver-speak.

6	2	lib/document.py
49	16	lib/layer/data.py

commit 34da84d87a2010ff42231730be55e25a7d7c9504
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-07-01 19:23:56 +0100

    Add namespace for MyPaint's OpenRaster extensions
    
    MyPaint needs to store a number of additional fields in OpenRaster files
    for its own benefit. The natural way of doing this in XML is to use a
    namespace, so I've picked "http://mypaint.org/ns/openraster" - which isn't
    an addressable resource yet, but it a) doesn't have to be, and b) could be
    one day if it's useful to have something there.
    
    Okay, OpenRaster doesn't even have its own xmlns yet, but no reason not to
    be ahead of the curve.
    
    Addresses mypaint/mypaint#18.

14	0	lib/xml.py

commit 2b48c67546fdacc7a6340156962bb15c3215f416
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-06-26 22:12:49 +0100

    pixbufsurface: raise AllocationError appropriately
    
    GdkPixbuf.Pixbuf.new() currently loves to raise TypeError when it fails to
    allocate the pixbuf, but it could basically be any sort of error return
    depending on how the annotations change. Catch the obvious oopsies and give
    the user a "hey, couldn't allocate $IMPORTANT_THING" message.
    
    Addresses mypaint/mypaint#62.
    
    Also update the docstrings and comments.

43	4	lib/pixbufsurface.py

commit 595725ff97e4d1306015cf281744b207ef2ec625
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-06-26 22:05:25 +0100

    lib.errors: add OOM wrapper exception class
    
    Code which is capable of detecting possible OOM conditions should log
    whatever condition or exception it has to hand, then raise a
    lib.errors.AllocationError in its stead with a translated user-facing
    message string.
    
    Code expecting to receive one of these and provide hints to the user should
    also catch MemoryError too, to be on the safe side. AllocationError is for
    when you suspect GI-wrapped code failed due to OOM and spat out a NULL or a
    different exception.

29	1	lib/errors.py

commit 66739df60998379bbf1e304eab30f6845941ddfd

    symmetry: UI to set the axis's alpha
    
    The axis of symmetry can be a bit visually intrusive while painting.
    
    This commit lets the user set an alpha value between 0% and 100% for the
    symmetry axis line while painting: it adds a slider in the options panel
    for the Symmetry Axis adjust tool. Setting the alpha to zero will make the
    axis invisible. The effect is immediately previewable in the axis edit mode
    you set the alpha from, so it should be reasonably obvious and
    discoverable.
    
    Closes mypaint/mypaint#295.

38	0	gui/symmetry.py

commit 07d873b0ddd2c546c0e5e12d796ecfa4fc995592
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-06-26 15:03:10 +0100

    symmetry: draw line using an alpha read from prefs
    
    Draw the symmetry line and its shadow to the same cairo group, which is
    then rendered with alpha. The base alpha can be set by the user in the
    on-disk prefs (UI TBA in next few commits).
    
    The alpha ultimately used while editing the line varies with the cursor's
    distance from the axis, making it look more active and allowing the user to
    preview their choice for the value of the alpha setting. While the cursor
    is far away, the alpha is whatever the user will choose in the panel UI.
    When the cursor is directly on top of the axis, the alpha is 100%.
    
    Addresses mypaint/mypaint#295.

30	0	gui/symmetry.py

commit be6cd1cbb7bae368872ba64a36af635d760a5103
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-06-26 14:55:27 +0100

    symmetry: always draw the line shadow
    
    There will be a user-settable alpha with a default of ⅓ when
    mypaint/mypaint#295 is fixed, so the line will be less overt.
    However the fact that it's a black outline to a white feature
    should make the line easier to distinguish against backdrops
    despite that.

6	7	gui/symmetry.py

commit 51c652b6902e78414a1702d80d7308d058477df4
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-06-23 05:15:54 +0100

    Brushwork cmd: hide+log rare exception case
    
    Fix a rare exception that can occasionally bubble up from certain unclear
    input sequences (bouncing from a painting layer to a non- painting one,
    then forcing a commit when no stroke was recorded?):
    
      AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'stop_recording'
    
    It's safe to ignore this, however. No stroke means no work done.

1	1	brushlib

commit 183cd18b9ff6deb4effb9ae59de3a1aa70477a9d
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-06-22 02:18:48 +0100

    SConstruct: validate prefix much less
    
    Our porters sometimes wish to install with
    
      scons prefix=/opt/nonexistent --install-sandbox=/somewhere/else
    
    however SCons's current handling of PathVariables makes this
    impossible, and even validator=PathVariable.PathAccept doesn't work.
    
    * Now accept nonexistent paths
    * Now only require that the path is syntactically absolute
    
    Drawback with this: if the prefix doesn't exist, users may reasonably
    expect that it will be created. The docs will need to be updated to
    tell users to do "scons prefix=/tmp/nonexistant install" instead.
    
    Possibly addresses mypaint/mypaint#347.

8	1	SConstruct

commit 819043a7e1dcd6ac37712df4c8b318bbbc30988e
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-06-22 01:14:02 +0100

    install_perms: apply dir permissions always
    
    Rip out the broken sandbox detection (always detected unsandboxed
    with "prefix=/ --install-sandbox=/any/where"). We now apply the
    permissions for all installs.
    
    Possibly partly addresses mypaint/mypaint#347.

21	25	SConstruct

commit 8929ceb2f7c9f0393fdaf6699aca80ce5827981e
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-06-21 04:18:56 +0100

    Update action strings, make accel editor searchable
    
    Massive update to the strings used for actions to make them more
    internally consistent and more useful in the accel map editor.
    The accel editor now uses the tooltip string to explaining what
    certain ambiguous labels mean, so all bindable actions now require
    tooltips.
    
    The accel editor is now searchable with keys (you need to give
    it focus 1st), and is sorted by default.
    
    Now favour "flip" mode-actions for keybinding, and don't show their
    equivalent radio mode-actions.
    
    Add translation contexts for all actions.
    
    Reorder the menus a bit.
    
    Closes mypaint/mypaint#28.
    Closes mypaint/mypaint#27.

    been mapped.

2	2	gui/preferenceswindow.glade

commit fe1a0877e1a6ac06704ec724d4506d3b0a0339fe
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-06-17 00:48:34 +0100

    Fix exception with weird interleaved input streams
    
    Fixes an OverflowError exception seemingly caused by the pressure and tilt
    interpolator we use in certain input cases: just clamp all pressure and
    tilt data before feeding it to the C/swig brush engine wrappers.
    
    The problem can arise in cases where zero-tilt data interleaves with tilted
    data, for example when knocking a mouse bound to the same pointer as a
    tablet you're currently drawing with.  It doesn't happen with all
    combinations of input device though, for unclear reasons (lacking axes? Bad
    data on some axes?)
    
    The interpolation method we use seems to be responsible, but for now we can
    just work around the resultant bad data from it.
    
    Closes mypaint/mypaint#344.

12	6	gui/freehand.py

commit 1c3a7c0d9f27d19862765fae77f9f1ce5e2488c2
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-06-17 00:51:20 +0100

    Properly handle backwards-dtime events
    
    This looks like a typo: we should be faking the time then treating
    the events as the zero-dtime events they now are, rather than then
    dropping them on the floor.

commit d43eb1a0e17db78b0226c294bf5f27dd4ca92e77
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-06-07 01:26:48 +0100

    Allow smooth scrolling to be turned off globally
    
    Smooth scrolling was proving annoying to our testers. However the new
    behaviour can only truly be turned off by unsetting the event mask and
    making GDK deliver discrete/stepwise scroll events for all devices.
    
    Add a checkbox to the View tab of the prefs window that turns off smooth
    scrolling for all TDWs after a restart.
    
    Also fix the layout of some labels in the dialog on that tab.
    
    Closes mypaint/mypaint#328.

commit 4e8a6b57ba1bf99ff0bc8dde9ba72f2262384479
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-06-05 20:54:28 +0100

    Use a MenuButton for toolbar brush/color menus
    
    Using the old GtkMenuToolButton hack for the toolnbar's brush and color
    menus looked confusing.  Replace them with a GtkToolItem containing a
    GtkMenuButton, which has been around since GTK 3.6.
    
    There's no such thing as a MenuButtonToolItem in GTK, so still need to
    implement our own along with the action architecture to bring it up.
    
    Closes mypaint/mypaint#143.

commit 266e56e2ff991f80df8ad3b8f6a2ba9835c860e1
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-06-04 21:04:29 +0100

    Fix popup color selectors thrashing when dragged
    
    The old C-rendered colour selectors (Wash, and Crossed Bowl) are very
    thrashy when clicked and dragged. This commit fixes that by making the
    colour they're editing only change when the pointer is released.
    
    Closes mypaint/mypaint#337.

16	0	gui/colors/adjbases.py
18	7	gui/colors/changers.py

commit ad107b3b51ba84daa4cdb4653fd7eb9843c2451d
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-06-04 20:24:47 +0100

    inktool: fix options panel exception after undo
    
    If the pending stroke is rolled back, the options panel needs to be made
    insensitive too. If we don't, and the user adjusts a points setting, an
    exception occurs.

1	0	gui/inktool.py

commit 08192e52f174f3d0de47c7e011a75cec87eeab41
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-06-04 20:02:24 +0100

    layermanip: make invisible layers immovable too
    
    Prevent LayerMoveMode from moving layers which cannot be seen - either
    because they are themselves invisible, or because they are nested inside an
    invisible layer.
    
    Closes mypaint/mypaint#238.

commit b6d06a46f93065e31b9cc21143f05155bfec974f
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-05-31 23:49:11 +0100

    Feature: add display filtering
    
    Resurrecting my old private branch, and updating it for git master.
    This commit adds filtering of the composited output. Filters include:
    
    * Greyscale (sRGB luma)
    * Inverse video
    * Simulated dichromat colour blindness:
      - Deuteranopia (Daltonism; 1% of males)
      - Protanopia (1% of males)
      - Tritanopia (<1% of population, not sex-linked)
    
    Closes mypaint/mypaint#332.

86	0	gui/displayfilter.py
23	0	gui/drawwindow.py
9	0	gui/menu.xml
68	0	gui/resources.xml
4	2	gui/tileddrawwidget.py
4	1	lib/layer/tree.py

commit b7836aa859efba453a983f6f3384507926fa2da2
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-05-23 21:23:29 +0100

    Use GDK_WINDOW_TYPE_HINT_UTILITY for color details
    
    GNOME has some shady default behaviour here, which makes transient colour
    dialogs with the default hints worse than useless for art programs since
    the dialog has a colour picker. Pretending it's a tool palette or similar
    allows more sensible picker behaviour while allowing us to retain the modal
    and transient-for flags we want.
    
    Closes mypaint/mypaint#325.

8	0	gui/dialogs.py

commit c02c09609915e8e44ae833a8a3bfb5d49c34cf61
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-05-10 20:02:14 +0100

    tdw: renderer doesn't need its own GdkWindow
    
    GTK3's PyGI wrappings still give GtkDrawingAreas their own window by
    default, unlike basically all other GI wrappings and unlike the documented
    C API. Ugh.
    
    Deciding which tdw a particular device is over becomes much harder if it
    does this, so turn it off. It'll draw to its parent EventBox quite happily.

9	0	gui/tileddrawwidget.py

commit cef02fd83f608e78c70e2606d21024fd29226f3b
Author: Andrew Chadwick <andrewc-git@piffle.org>
Date:   2013-11-12 03:20:55 +0000

    quick choosers: add color popup, common base
    
    The dialog-based popup chooser for the brush chooser was proving annoying
    with my window manager, so switch to a resizable popup-window based
    implementation which uses the same kind of pointer leave mechanism for
    cancelling.
    
    Add a colour chooser popup based on the same thing, for some visual
    similarity. That goes on "C"; remove the old color changer on "V"
    temporarily. The colour chooser is also accessible by clicking on the
    bottom left "current colour" button.

commit 79f912405ad54528bea353ef5b1bb5895a052fa4
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-04-19 16:54:31 +0100

    Modes: add flag for 0alpha *always* clearing bg
    
    Tile compositing applies several optimizations based on the idea that
    some modes always clear their backdrop if the src layer has zero alpha,
    and some leaves it unchanged with a zero src alpha.
    
    Express the zero_alpha_clears_backdrop case with its own flag.
    
    Rework the tile loop during compositing. I think this is right now...

commit 94505b0b53fed7d429fb01d02f6e5a850c02ac5b
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-04-09 23:20:42 +0100

    Revert "fastpng: release GIL during blocking IO"
    
    Was causing corruption when saving or exporting PNGs, seemingly only ones
    with non-multiple-of-TILE_SIZE frames. See mypaint/mypaint#287.
    
    The commit was slightly unnecessary anyway, and it's no big loss.
    We don't use threads for background saving currently,
    and probably never will, but we might've one day.
    
    This reverts commit a16f34f5faab08867d8a412b0c056b10520ece74.

14	31	lib/fastpng.cpp

commit 98fbab2d52da86ec73584d4baa30b4892cc6bb6f
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-04-09 01:08:51 +0100

    nav-only devices: let btn1 start drags like btn2
    
    If a hardware ("slave") device is configured to be a navigation-only
    device, then treat its button-1 as a supplementary button-2 for the purposes
    of initiating temporary mode switches based on pointer clicks and drags.
    By default, button-2 does navigation (viewport panning, rotation, and
    zooming).
    
    This allows single-finger drags with an appropriately configured
    touchscreen, in lieu of real touchscreen support. The AllowedUsage setting
    for a device (navigation-only vs. allowed-for-painting) is also how I want
    to distinguish between the finger-painting and single-finger-panning styles
    when we *do* implement real touchscreen support, so let's build in a bit of
    that behaviour now.
    
    This is roughly the way the space bar drags work, so it's not that weird a
    concept. Really!
    
    Okay, it's slightly experimental, and let's rip this out if it breaks
    stuff. However, it does have a nice feel on my XPS13.
    
    Closes mypaint/mypaint#246.

30	14	gui/document.py

Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-04-06 19:08:05 +0100

    Merge feature: recovery from autosaved backups
    
    If MyPaint crashes, your working state can now be reloaded from disk
    provided MyPaint was idle for long enough to consider starting a
    background save. This behaviour can be tweaked or turned off if it
    becomes annoying.
    
    Fixes mypaint/mypaint #90.
    Closes mypaint/mypaint #264.

commit a16f34f5faab08867d8a412b0c056b10520ece74
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-03-31 23:22:04 +0100

    fastpng: release GIL during blocking IO
    
    We might use threads one day for the queue runner here, depending on
    whether de-prioritizing it is still going to be needed. There are potential
    wins and losses either way. Turns out the poor threaded performance in
    earlier experiments was just down to not letting Python run other threads
    during blocking IO.
    
    The usual style applies: no calls into Python while the GIL's released,
    store local copies of everything including a buffer of the strip to be
    written in the write state object to protect against something else
    deallocating or writing that array's data (which is IMO slightly paranoid,
    but hey it could happen).
    
    Strips must now only be big enough to fit within the internal write buffer,
    which is one tile row high.

31	14	lib/fastpng.cpp

commit 5e50cdd4f608b02e4aa3c3407cc0aeb9b4579ef6
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-03-21 03:14:50 +0000

    Better naming for per-doc cache subfolders
    
    Make the folders and file names found in user cache areas more consistent,
    and hopefully more understandable. MyPaint's cache area now looks like:
    
    <cache-root>/mypaint/ - app+user-specific area
     └─ doc.XXXXXX/ - area specific to a loaded document
         ├─ edits/ - files actively being edited in an external app
         ├─ revisions/ - revisions of file-backed layers, 1 per undo step
         ├─ tmp/ - occasional use for unpacking files etc.
         └─ autosave/ - OpenRaster-like tree, kept updated & consistent
             ├─ data/
             └─ Thumbnails/
    
    The subfolders below doc.XXXXXX are created on demand, meaning that some
    may be missing for some kinds of document, or at different stages during
    the document's life cycle.

20	6	lib/layer/core.py
87	39	lib/layer/data.py
27	12	lib/layer/group.py
19	9	lib/layer/tree.py

commit 189e1952cf30038adcd38a95562c531e5a83c0e3
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-04-06 18:43:37 +0100

    gui.mode: Smooth scrolling, no rotation
    
    Stop scrolling doing rotation. This was *incredibly* disconcerting with
    touchpads configured to do bidirectional scrolling. This is not an uncommon
    configuration these days.
    
    Fixes mypaint/mypaint#204.
    
    Scrolling is now smooth for devices which support it. Hold down Shift to
    make smooth scrolls discrete again (i.e. to make it work like before).
    
    Hold down Alt or Ctrl to pan instead of zooming.
    
    If we want to support scroll rotation again, suggest Ctrl+Scroll. But it's
    absent for now because I don't really see a nice way of doing it.
    
    Zooming is still the default behaviour when unconfigured, but MyPaint now
    supports panning rather than zooming as the unmodified action for a
    device's scroll events. This can be configured in the device preferences,
    and can be different between devices.

128	18	gui/mode.py
2	0	gui/tileddrawwidget.py
4	1	gui/viewmanip.py

commit 2dcf5deff5bf0fb27431333c3263bfa3e2ce49bd

commit f879520ef70befb82dceeb6696f718867e74ab2a
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-03-29 22:34:45 +0100

    Add wrappers for GLib-style gettext
    
    GLib defines nicer wrappers around gettext than the standard Python
    gettext library in 2.7. Add a wrapper module allowing us to migrate to it
    in due course.
    
    Complete API: https://git.gnome.org/browse/glib/tree/glib/gi18n-lib.h
    We probably just want C_() as the most Pythonic of these options though,
    with something like the old way of doing _() to support older code.
    And ngettext() of course.
    
    Partly addresses #278.

commit f4da91af6a0f18cff5ddd387bde457802ab73a1a
Merge: 4d5bd9b3 e7a5ad28
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>

commit 2002f926beb0f51785e46d01f880ce40f5c9eb76
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-03-21 02:51:30 +0000

    [feature] Make auto-saves when changes settle
    
    Write an autosave folder out to the cache after a short period of
    inactivity following a change. The file trees now written to
    <cache>/mypaint/doc.XXXXXX/autosave resemble OpenRaster files in structure,
    and should have useful guarantees of internal consistency.
    
    The <cache> folder used for all of this is the one GLib tells us (see
    the docs for g_get_user_cache_dir()). On POSIX systems we use
    $XDG_CACHE_HOME, normally $HOME/.cache. On Windows 7, a typical path is
    %LOCALAPPDATA%\Microsoft\Windows\Temporary Internet Files, which has the
    disadvantage of being a hidden location (but then, so is Linux's with the
    dot-name and everything).
    
    The idea is to give people a way of recovering files when mypaint crashes
    hard when changes haven't been saved to an output file. If it does, and
    you're lucky enough to have a good autosave backup, you should be able to
    zip it into a new .ora file and recover data that way.
    
    Partly addresses mypaint/mypaint#90.
    For a full solution, we'll need a real auto-recovery dialog.
    
    Consistency
    -----------
    
    If you see a file named stack.xml in an autosave "doc.*" folder, then
    everything it indexes can be expected to exist, and it should even have a
    valid thumbnail. Neither stack.xml nor the files it indexes will be
    partially written if they exist at all, assuming the file system hasn't
    failed.
    
    This code doesn't attempt to guarantee consistency when *filesystems*
    crash, although some measure of security could be gained there by using
    flushes and fsync() calls. There are however good performance reasons not
    to do that, and MyPaint already tries to provide good data robustness when
    saving normally.
    
    Performance
    -----------
    
    The bulk of the work is found in saving big layer images and their
    strokemaps. To keep auto-saving responsive, this code queues all the
    writes in lots of separate idletask chunks, at a very low priority.
    Hopefully this means that autosaves don't interfere too much with
    high-priority foreground stuff like event capture and brush engine
    performance.
    
    Layers now have an autosave_dirty flag which must be set when their file
    data should be saved. Autosave passes don't write more then they need to.
    
    I'd like to use threads for this, but the interactive performance when I
    tried that seemed *remarkably* bad. The writes just choke off all other
    activity, perhaps for GIL-related reasons? The fact that you can't lower
    the priority of Python threads doesn't help much either.

114	0	lib/autosave.py
144	18	lib/document.py
3	0	lib/idletask.py
236	42	lib/layer/data.py
22	1	lib/layer/group.py
34	0	lib/layer/tree.py
71	0	lib/tiledsurface.py

commit d1cbcd676531bee7fff4cac0d43b770d8cb78f48

9	0	lib/idletask.py

commit 0d5516ab73dfa582a3084d5e4f48f525a88bda2f
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-03-19 19:40:32 +0000

    idletask: tweak protocol, modernize code
    
    Change the interface slightly: now the task callables are called
    until they return False and only then discarded.
    This makes more sense if your callable is a big hairy object
    with lots of internal iterators or other state, but it doesn't
    affect any of the existing code.
    
    General code preen too:
    
    * Schedule via GLib not GObject (was deprecated)
    * Use the standard deque for the queue (because may as well)
    * Some little docs updates.

commit b9ed29be9ec29c99eee4cacb1971e92d5e5f4396
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-03-10 01:10:37 +0000

    Palette view: handle widgets with null bg colours
    
    Using Adwaita in GTK 3.14.5 makes style contexts sometimes return null
    background colours (alpha=0) for certain widget arrangements. This presents
    as black even for the light variant when run through later processing.
    
    Fix by ascending the widget tree until we find a valid background colour
    and using that.
    
    Addresses mypaint/mypaint#249.

20	10	gui/colors/paletteview.py

commit 6b3a1e7f21e6cc597baa31a48f6947ced9f760e3
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-03-06 14:03:23 +0000

    Remove overrides for gtk-dnd-drag-threshold
    
    Overriding this was causing issues with sensitivity in the layers menu,
    and doing it twice resulted in the dnd sensitivity being dependent on
    panel initialization order. In other words, different people were getting
    different results :/
    
    Addresses mypaint/mypaint#240.
    
    This may make brush dragging, or clicking in the brush lists, seem
    oversensitive to some people (that's the reason the override that the
    override was there at all, IIRC). Testing would be appreciated.
    
    The primary way to adjust this right now is by configuring your settings
    manager with a more comfortable drag threshold. On GNOME or Ubuntu Unity,
    try
    
    gsettings set org.gnome.settings-daemon.peripherals.mouse drag-threshold 16
    
    if the default of 8 pixels is bothersome.

commit ba0649b7bea0c12656877476827cff2aa9468032
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-03-05 20:26:22 +0000

    Layers: require a single click for eye/lock icons
    
    Double-clicking the eye icon was firing triple sets of changes at the model
    for the 1st & 2nd click events, and Gdk's manufactured double click event.
    For some reason it was getting the column wrong for the 3rd one (packing
    flow, updates, brief window of zero width maybe?)
    
    Fix mypaint/mypaint#234 by requiring the events that change the model to be
    those initial single click events only.

commit d12f42585d04758d90163789553b05f2866a75e7

commit 2705b937217761d32687eccc38464fd85f14cebe
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-03-05 18:26:00 +0000

    Layers panel: do our own drag-and-drop handling
    
    Rip out the old dtd implementation (using the high-level GtkTreeDragSource
    and GtkTreeDragDest interfaces), and replace it with low-level dnd handlers
    on the corresponding view.
    
    Relying on these interfaces was proving very unreliable from one version of
    GTK to another for reasons I can't quite fathom. I suspect it's to do with
    GtkSelectionData access and typelib annotation of its manipulation funcs,
    but I'm not certain.
    
    The low-level dnd interface shared by everything should be more stable and
    reasonably permanent, and has the advantage that upstream actually test it.
    
    Fixes mypaint/mypaint#148.

201	62	gui/layers.py

commit 1b72581eb590fb8167561b656cd9a6b798bb2be2
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-03-05 18:22:17 +0000

    Refactor: move layer tree model
    
    Move the layer TreeView to a side module away from the panel one to allow
    independent testing of it.
    
    Keep the current broken way of handling drags, for now.  This will be
    replaced with low-level GTK DnD code because the annotations for
    gtk_tree_set_row_drag_data() and its get() cousin have historically been
    very broken, and because our use of the high level interface just stopped
    working one day. I basically give up trying to use the high-level GTK
    listview DnD protocol at this point; we have too many versions of GTK to
    support for the next release.
    
    This drops the ability to move into/under a non-group layer using the shift
    key. It was cool functionality, but it's in the way when doing this kind of
    rewrite.
    
    Addresses mypaint/mypaint#148.

commit eb76974969448486487feb08110981034f55fb11
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-02-27 02:47:43 +0000

    Ink tool: workaround for dropouts with evdev
    
    Workaround for evdev drivers sending zero pressure when the pressure has
    not changed since the last event. Yes, it's this bug again!
    
    This affects lots of cheap, popular Monoprice, Genius and Huion tablets,
    and probably other brands. If your tablet has "UC-Logic" in the name X11
    presents, it probably needs this.
    
    Closes #223 (tested with Wacom Intos5 + evdev driver)
    
    Much of this inktool stuff has been sitting around in a local branch of
    mine for ages, since before the fix for #29.

commit 9082fbd6fdbe211ab833fb531613a12e926c6113
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-02-26 23:09:46 +0000

    Add a basic Inking tool
    
    Add a tool for making smooth, controllable curves. The idea is that it's
    a bit like freehand mode, but allows the last curve you drew to be tweaked
    just after you drew it.
    
    It works in two phases:
    
    1. Draw a line to record a sequence of control points
    2. Tweak the control points
    3. Accept or reject the tweaked curve with onscreen buttons,
       or just start a fresh one
    
    Curve rendering uses a basic Catmull-Rom spline, but we can change it to
    something fancier later.  Re-rendering happens in an idle routine to allow
    the curve points to be adjusted responsively.
    
    Closes mypaint/mypaint#13

-	-	desktop/icons/hicolor/scalable/actions/mypaint-ok-symbolic.svg
1	0	gui/document.py
684	0	gui/inktool.py

commit f5b5541cf41c9aead4fc532421910952552f04ae
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-02-24 00:12:01 +0000

    Brushwork leave(): only commit if leaving finally
    
    The inking mode is a subclass of this one, and it often has quite a lot of
    changes up in the air which haven't been committed yet. Just stacking
    another mode on top of it, such as a temporary panning mode, shouldn't
    commit OR roll back pending brushwork.

commit 30f5382536caa7dda01ee702ada355d2274ffcd6
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-02-24 14:00:55 +0000

    Fix broken saving of compatibility bg layers
    
    MyPaint was using entirely the wrong bounding box when saving out its
    background in a way that other apps can understand, and was declaring the
    wrong offset for it as well.
    
    The base class can't trust a derived class's data bbox for this sort of
    thing because background layers don't really have a sensible data bbox
    (they're *everywhere* in a deep sense).
    
    Fix by letting the layer implementations declare their own offsets when
    saving (or declare no offsets), and also by generating the tiled PNG image
    at the size of the frame rather than some amorphous and very clearly wrong
    union size of all tiles in all *other* layers.
    
    Quickly addresses mypaint/mypaint#214, but this needs testing.

36	35	lib/layer.py

commit 496e016846c5019810395aac315cfd72858010e7
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-02-14 03:36:34 +0000

    Reset brush on startup, and after Escape
    
    Resetting the brush state properly when the app starts up avoids anyone
    seeing ugly strokes from (0,0) to the first motion event when the event has
    pressure.  It seems nicest to manage this reset using the interaction mode
    stack and its automated construction of a default mode instance.  This
    keeps ordinary auto-splits continuous, and allows colour changing via
    history mid-stroke without pressure discontinuities.
    
    Fixes #11.

1	1	gui/document.py
38	23	gui/mode.py
14	5	lib/command.py

commit 50a737b69a0772526b09d120b80f17dd8362604a
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-02-14 02:37:37 +0000

    Fix segfault when dragging tabs in gtk 3.14.8
    
    Quick and dirty fix for a segfault seen when dragging tabs to make a new
    window in the newest stable release of GTK. The fault is ours; we're
    playing fast and loose with what GTK expected in a handler with defined
    job. We're still cheating, but in a way that doesn't freak GTK out.
    
    Fixes mypaint/mypaint#194.

32	0	gui/workspace.py

commit 5690ea677575c64c8efa47044ca5dc4f3d4ce59b
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-02-13 01:14:57 +0000

    Undo stack fixes for brushwork/freehand modes
    
    Give the brushwork undo-stack command and brushwork modes some love. The
    code's now more understandable (to me, anyway). It's much more careful
    about its state too, both when strokes are being recorded and around do()
    and undo().
    
    Fixes mypaint/mypaint#174. Looks like this was caused by a failure to
    discard the command being recorded after splitting it.
    
    lib.command.Brushwork:
    
    * The stop_recording() method now reports whether tiles changed
      - the mode no longer has to fumble around with a reflected stroke API
      - more informative debug message when committing strokes
    * fix up some comments
    * make the phases clearer
    * various code cleanups
    * add more assertions
    * simplify code: it's super-stateful, so just keep a real ref to the
      layer while recording
    
    gui.mode.BrushworkModeMixin:
    
    * simplify code paths
      - now just one place that brushwork commit happens
      - assertions to catch state fuckups
    
    lib.layer:
    
    * remove a line of unused code

commit 2c96580e3dffcdd2a68a551518c8c93fd5c1aefa
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-02-11 16:29:36 +0000

    Layer loading: fix initial selection logic
    
    The old code was producing paths for the initial selection which didn't
    exist in the document due to using only a simple count.
    This would have been only apparent when the loaded document had no layers
    marked as selected *and* also had nested layers.
    
    Closes #196. Thanks for the report and investigation, @vurentjie!
    
    Taking the opportunity to fix up the logic so that it selects either a) the
    topmost layer that's marked with selected="true", or b) the topmost
    immediate child layer of the root, which is always something that exists.
    I think using the highest-up layer when we have multiple choices will be
    more convenient for users.

    nicer.

commit f866d426ce125da388dcedbb25937e2ba3eac8ee
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-02-08 23:42:58 +0000

    Improve failed-drag bailout code
    
    Bail-out code can be called during enter() or leave(), and since the effect
    is to cause the top mode to leave(), that can lead to inconsistent internal
    state. To correct it, make the real bailout happen in an idle routine.
    
    Remove some debugging crud.
    
    Addresses #182 partially.

commit 4ffe1a1cd560e0ee6a3910effd7d9f1939b4bacb

Date:   2015-02-07 07:40:33 +0000

    fastpng: work around GIMP gamma issues, refactor
    
    Move fastpng stuff out into a separate compilation unit. It was getting
    untidy and exposing messy crap via swig.
    
    Lots of formatting changes.
    
    Add a nasty workaround for GIMP's unhelpful advertising of its "sRGB built-in"
    default working space as "ɣ=2.2, deal with it" when saving PNGs. Sigh.
    To salvage some dignity, I've added cases for not performing any
    transformations when loading PNGs, and the workaroud is now one of those.
    
    Fixes mypaint/mypaint#129.

commit f56c546ea8cba647aeb49ba83573e03050fa7946
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-01-31 02:35:30 +0000

    Save PNG/ORA: use the "display is sRGB" flag
    
    If MyPaint is assuming the display is sRGB, save sRGB (and fallback cHRM
    and gAMA) chunks when saving PNG files.
    
    Otherwise, no assumption about the display is being made so we can't say
    anything: we don't save the chunks.

commit 591e7fb8d96d279ee713e4a62c474cbbdbb92906
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-01-31 02:31:21 +0000

    Load PNG/ORA: use "display is sRGB" flag
    
    If MyPaint is assuming that the display is sRGB, then convert PNG files to
    that space when loading if they have embedded file colour space
    information.
    
    Otherwise, fall back to the legacy behaviour where we just assume loaded
    PNG and ORA files match the display space regardless of their colour
    management chunks.

commit 4c4d0fe529c2aaa27bbc8273f24343f6c4088925
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-01-30 18:33:21 +0000

    PNGs: save sRGB chunks (and appropriate cHRM/gAMA)
    
    My current thinking is to save what we assume, and assume that the user
    has calibrated their display to something approximating sRGB when working
    with MyPaint.
    
    Yes, this is a bad assumption, yes we should be using real display space
    transformations *if* they are available: mypaint/mypaint#9. However it's a
    backwards-compatible assumption for MyPaint's purposes, and hopefully a
    minimally interoperable one.
    
    Addresses one of the issues noticed in mypaint/mypaint#129.
    
    The existence of non-sRGB-tagged PNG data in a .ORA file *cannot* be relied
    upon to identify files saved with old stable MyPaint releases because the
    GIMP ORA plugin has been known to save a gAMA chunk only (i.e. no cHRM, no
    sRGB), housing a value that is (presumably) either derived from display
    gamma or an sRGB assumed default.

1	2	lib/pixbufsurface.py

commit cc0894b7e3c960b9b810c8b351cd687efa9e990f
Author: Jenny Wong <jy2wong@csclub.uwaterloo.ca>
Date:   2015-02-02 23:04:38 -0500

    Introduce SAVE_FORMAT_PNGAUTO
    
    SAVE_FORMAT_PNGAUTO is a special PNG save format for when the user does
    not explicitly choose to save a solid or transparent PNG (i.e. when the
    user does a 'save as' with a filename ending in '.png' without touching
    the 'Format to save as' dropdown menu, or when the user tries to 'save'
    a PNG after previously doing a 'save as').
    
    If the background is visible, a solid PNG will be saved. Otherwise, a
    transparent PNG will be saved.
    
    Fixes the other half of github issue 165.

5	4	gui/filehandling.py
3	1	lib/document.py

commit 77b5747ae10e2bc7223a59a57286bda3744b6f64
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-01-14 17:55:54 +0000

    Fix Win32 exception on bad saves-via-tempfile
    
    Native Windows file handling is weird.
    
    Attempting to clean up the tempfile after a (tempfile) save fails with an
    exception can itself raise an exception on this platform: it may still be
    open. Convert it to a logged but nonfatal error, but still raise the
    original exception.

commit 7c23ae4db0744793df826de59943fb01a0389486
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>

Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-01-12 18:45:44 +0000

    Allow local testing on all platforms
    
    The Win32 platform should support testing from the source directory too, or
    we're never going to be able to fix Windows bugs in a timely fashion.
    Therefore, do the "am I still in my source tree?" test up front, somewhat
    more explicitly.
    
    NOTE: even with this code, MyPaint currently assumes a py2exe bundling if
    it's run on win32 from somewhere other than the source tree. This should be
    changed, or checked.

commit 6947ad972516b8ae92262152d0047ccb79edf149
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2015-01-02 20:54:25 +0000

    Fix exception when moving a layer by tile size multiples
    
    Caused by a failure to init some internal records properly, which then
    highlighted some incorrect bookkeeping during the idle-cycle processing
    part of the move. Only tile moves of whole-tile offsets were affected.
    
    Fixes #161.
    Er, I guess the testing we did before never hit this path.
    Weird. Embarrassing.
    
    Anyway, add doctest for future regression-proofing (and illustrating
    all-in-one move processing too, I guess).

    LCMS2 if it's available on your system.

commit c43e6d1336b471dbe0209c470ea7912024b3c520
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-11-28 20:16:01 +0000

    Make symmetry state properties of the root stack
    
    Symmetry state (whether symmetrical painting is active, and the axis
    position) are global properties of the document structure, and must be
    reflected into layers when things change to keep the brush engine
    informed.  The natural place for them is the root of the layer stack.
    
    Deprecate the old methods for setting the symmetry axis.

    that as the option is under the "Layer" submenu, the "Layer" part is
    inherent, but that doesn't hold up as there's plenty of other items that
    explicitly say "layer", such as "New Layer", "Normalize Layer Mode",
    etc.

1	1	gui/resources.xml

commit 00d3914f2c23d752e1fe3267407f2a44f056c813
Author: iirelu <totallymyrealemail@hush.ai>
Date:   2014-11-25 13:39:08 +0000

    Ripped out legacy Psyco code
    
    Psyco has been unmaintained for years and in all likelihood doesn't even
    work with Mypaint, thanks to swig. In the unlikely case Psyco was
    installed, Mypaint would probably just fail to start.

0	23	mypaint.py

commit 61ba5536ce66a5a98a79398c083017b47cc5f2d4
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-11-21 03:57:07 +0000

    Default bg: use fallback image, no dark-theme test
    
    Use a nice fallback image if default.png doesn't exist. We don't ship a
    standard default.png now.
    
    No longer test whether MyPaint is configured to use dark themes to decide
    the default background. Not every theme will have a "dark" variant, and
    some themes are dark by default. Better to not try to be too clever, and
    pick a fallback colour and fallback image that works OK for both dark and
    light surrounds.

19	6	gui/application.py
1	0	gui/backgroundwindow.py

commit 0fe8976706cbda60b36af983912a4dce486c4775
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-11-21 03:37:38 +0000

    Backgrounds: be less fussy, use PyGI syntax.
    
    * Allow JPEG images to be used in the background library
    * Walk background library directories recursively to find candidates
    * Permit background images to be used which have alpha
      - works by compositing onto a black background
    * Allow images that aren't a strict multiple of the tile size
      - works by tiling and repetition up to a preset limit
      - if that hits the lcm, that's great!
      - otherwise, scale closest fit encountered down to nearest tile multiple
      - hopefully still reasonably pretty and close to the original aspect
    * Project: update copyright
    * Coding: use PyGI syntax
    * Coding: various stylistic fixes
    * UI: tweak display of the background previews

309	111	gui/backgroundwindow.py

4	0	CONTRIBUTING.md

commit 1cee7a7b3fd72e7fe871e674f47ffa270811b9fb
Author: iirelu <totallymyrealemail@hush.ai>
Date:   2014-11-13 02:31:39 +0000

    Changed history-adding logic to only compare names
    
    Previously it used BrushInfo.matches to compare same-ness, which meant
    that if the user changed a small setting such as brush size, it would
    count as an entirely separate brush and have it's own entry in the brush
    history. This was undesirable, and simplifying the code to only compare
    the brush names makes the history less likely to be polluted with small
    changes.

3	1	gui/brushmanager.py

    around as the window changed size, but it's now more consistent.

commit 93104299f61b5babb647928e174b79f3fb4198a8
Author: Albert Westra <odysseywestra@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-11-06 11:21:31 -0800

    Popup Menu Fix
    
    Address the Problem in issue #94 where using a two finger
    tap/press(right-click) on Multi-Touch touchpads and clickpads causes the toolbar
    menu immediately unfocus. This was cause by the gdk.CURRENT_TIME. The
    fix was to use the gtk.get_current_event_time() which was used in
    the popup menu for the layers window.
    
    This should fix #94

commit 892adb6bb7a7c12b1fdea98c2aa056a082f147b2
Author: iirelu <totallymyrealemail@hush.ai>
Date:   2014-11-05 10:42:56 +0000

    Only auto-enable the frame on the first activation
    
    Fixes #79.
    
    The frame tool now keeps track of whether or not it's being activated
    for the first time. Previously, once it was switched back to after a
    panning/rotating/etc operation, the frame was automatically enabled
    regardless of whether it was before, which was very frustrating.
    
    However, if the frame is disabled and the user manually switches to the
    frame tool, it'll still be re-enabled. I'm not sure why this happens,
    but it is actually a desirable effect, as to the user functionality is
    near-identical but with one less bug.

7	1	gui/framewindow.py

commit d2060145274f5cbc93b5f179200bfd587e884249
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-11-03 23:57:08 +0000

    Remove keep-above forcing in fullscreen mode
    
    Window managers are a pain.
    
    Forcing keep-above for the main window in fullscreen mode breaks
    fullscreening entirely in Awesome WM. Therefore, rip out this hack:
    workarounds that completely break functionality that would otherwise work
    will be dropped.
    
    Xfwm4 will be annoying now if there are subwindows visible in fullscreen
    mode, so it's best to use the docks on this wm and unfullscreen when using
    the preferences window. I use xfwm4 myself. Sorry for the inconvenience.
    
    Unity doesn't seem too badly affected either way these days.
    
    Fixes #89.

0	17	gui/workspace.py

commit 6dc42fad5cd15efc48da2b8354ee1c9617761067
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-11-03 23:19:45 +0000

    Fix floating window title bars in Ubuntu
    
    Fix broken decoration flags. Ubuntu 14.04 wasn't showing window titlebars,
    for floating windows making them impossible to move.
    
    Remove some dead code.
    
    Update file copyright.

6	4	gui/workspace.py

commit bda5973cafb54bc79215ea08f5c363d81eb56a98
Author: iirelu <totallymyrealemail@hush.ai>
Date:   2014-11-03 21:07:10 +0000

    Removed a number of glob imports
    
    Glob imports meaning `from x import *`. I don't think it's called that
    in python.
    
    Glob imports are near-universally bad, as not only do they make
    statically detecting undefined variables impossible, they're also just a
    bad development practice to begin with.
    
    Quite a few remain in gui/colors/, but the imports in there are a
    complete and utter mess so I'm planning to refactor it around.

commit 631a2aeb2ccd024f4ec06e0ac817ca445f1ee006
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-10-21 19:25:40 +0100

    Follow symlinks when saving files, but not .BAK
    
    Trace symlinks to the real underlying path when the file to be saved over
    is a symlink (or addressed via a symlinked dir).
    
    Backup files however go in the place you requested, like gedit or vim.
    
    Fixes #115.

10	4	lib/fileutils.py

commit ffacdd7960af37c8b0c3f4b4ea3659124fb06405
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-10-21 15:54:30 +0100

    Run lib/meta.py to obtain release version
    
    Grepping  a special line out via the shell and eval'ing it is a dirty way
    of getting the base version string, and gets in the way of PEP8 compliance.
    Instead, run the metainfo module as a python script. Currently this just
    prints the value of MYPAINT_VERSION to STDOUT, but we could use the eval
    trick again if we need more info to be available to the release-time
    scripting.
    
    Fixes #113.
    
    (Also remove .travis.yml from the tarballs we'll distribute.)

9	3	lib/meta.py
2	2	release.sh

commit 217f6f0dbb39ce6af38dcd675c73b92ee076c528
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-10-14 19:20:14 +0100

    Fix segfault from new GTK when closing panel tabs
    
    Doing fancy structure-mangling stuff in our button handlers was interfering
    with GtkNotebook's own button handlers (as of GTK+ 3.14.3) and provoking
    segfaults when clicking on the "close tab" button in sidebars and floating
    windows.  Fix by deferring the tab removal.

commit c9f240081c8d171952483faff42f4031a9309ff8
Author: iirelu <totallymyrealemail@hush.ai>
Date:   2014-10-01 09:22:04 +0100

    Standardized on specific continuation indent style
    
    Entirely fixes PEP-8 errors E121, E122, E126, E127, and E128.
    
    From now on, when a function call is too long to fit on one line, it
    should look like one of the following:
    
    really_long_function_call(
        single_argument)
    
    function_call(
        first_argument,
        second_argument,
        third_argument
    )

commit 2c0a296ade8c505d09215d4d36df1469bbd458ee
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-09-01 19:42:54 +0100

    Implement fallback layers
    
    Allow layers that GdkPixmap knows about (other then PNG and SVG) to be
    handled via a fallback bitmap layer type. They're rendered on the canvas
    and can be moved around, and will be preserved and saved verbatim.
    
    Also preserve and display layer data that GdkPixmap *doesn't* grok. These
    get a small, ugly icon on the canvas showing the top-left corner of the
    layer, but that's it. After all, we don't even know their bounding box.
    The idea is that the user will see the mess and go sort these out in the
    app that created them. In this case, verbatim preservation on save rather
    than just silently dropping the layer is probably a good idea.
    
    Fallback layers of both types can be edited via their associated external
    app.
    
    Layers can be converted to painting layers using the Normalize function,
    although this may have unexpected behaviour in some cases. Perhaps we
    should add a "Convert Layer to Painting Layer" command?
    
    Both types of fallback layer get a "?" icon in the layers list.
    
    Fixes #101 (allow layers to be preserved and moved, even if unrenderable).
    Fixes #100 (as far as I want to take it right now, anyway).

-	-	desktop/icons/hicolor/scalable/actions/mypaint-layer-fallback-symbolic.svg
87	14	lib/layer.py

commit 44f34f151a4602d86e2c2c3817bedaf112e2d176
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-08-22 18:17:30 +0100

    New Vector Layer: use view area, immediate edits
    
    Instead of using a 64x64 blank SVG document for new vector layers, create
    them with the current MyPaint viewport outlined, and with a document size
    that encloses that outline. Closer to what people probably want, hopefully.
    
    Creating a new vector layer now launches the editor immediately.
    
    Show ellipses for the New Vector Layer commands: they require user input
    now.

commit ae343869d5b2b12b64bc75e4e03abb7092112d01
Merge: 1b78f8d7 5d50cdcd
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-08-06 01:43:26 +0100

    Support for vector layers (SVG, edited externally)
    
    Adds the ability to create vector layers and edit them in Inkscape (if
    that's your default SVG file opener). Some polishing may be needed, such as
    offering a choice from the DE's recommended SVG apps, but for now this
    should suffice and allow testing.
    
    Fixes #57.
    
    There seems to be a consensus on the CREATE mailing list that arbitrary
    image-like (or otherwise) layer file data is welcome in OpenRaster
    containers, and that this is the correct interpretation of the current
    spec. SVG is one of the more useful of these formats, since we gain useful
    text and graphics layers.
    
    To use this feature, create a new vector layer, then edit it with your
    favourite external app via the menu. When you save the temporary file, a
    new entry is created on the MyPaint undo stack.
    
    Rendering in MyPaint is ultimately via librsvg, meaning you may need to
    simplify Inkscape SVG files which rely on Inkscape-specific extensions
    quite a lot. If nothing displays at all, make sure your librsvg install
    ships a libpixbufloader-svg.so and that gdk-pixbuf-query-loaders lists SVG.

commit 1b78f8d79472c3666a189755f147ad9cc5ed4e5c
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-07-14 23:11:37 +0100

    Add device mode chooser UI
    
    * Add UI for setting devices as ignored for particular kinds of mode/task
      - Device permissions "All tasks", "Ignored", or "View manipulation only"
      - All devices are permitted for all tasks by default
      - Ignored events are silently discarded
      - Switching between modes with the pointer still works
      - Fixes #40.
    * Make the kinds of modes devices can interact with configurable:
      - Mode instances declare what sorts of actions they do
      - Device compat. with a mode depends on the mode's declared behaviour
    * Class hierarchy simplification & API improvements:
      - all events are now dispatched via the document controller
      - mode-switching now happens in the document controller
      - modes now declare whether they support pointer-based switching
      - Consolidate freehand modes into one
    * Improve statusbar messages for modifier + mouse button commands.

commit ef9bd3711860b74dbd1036db4ea5d478007dfd81
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>

    App launching: better messages, more sensible EAFP

commit 66ace429e0aba81ceacb0f2e1f12d8b723479def
Author: Albert Westra <odysseywestra@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-07-20 21:27:10 -0700

    Refined Two Symbolic Icons and Patched Export Script
    
    Refined the mypaint-tab-options, and the mypaint-fill symbolic icons to
    help the wrench flow with the theme, and the paint bucket look a bit
    better(it the small things).
    
    Also, it was getting anoying that one had to close Inkscape in order to
    finish the symbolic icon export. So adding a --verb=FileQuit command did
    the trick to close inkscape when it was finished.
    
    Lastly, notice that for some of the symbolic icons, the export script
    did not remove the bounding box of the icon. Fixed by adding a loop
    to looked for something that was common between the bounding boxes
    which they all start with "use". Simple Band-Aid fix, but I plan to open
    and issue about an alternate method on how to export the symbolic icons.

commit 14ad51641ed19881a88099cf7c97be43b75bde28
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-07-20 02:02:43 +0100

    Swig: use native support provided by SCons
    
    SCons version 2.1.0+ appear to support swig just fine, and provided you're
    careful about declaring inter-module dependencies the resultant project
    build order is correct too.
    
    * Use SCons's native swig support
    * Move the _mypaintlib.so → brushlib dependency into lib/ where it belongs
    
    Builds work correctly after a --clean, over many calls with --random, and
    rebuild correctly following changes in source deps correctly. Versions of
    scons tested: 2.1.0, 2.3.1.
    
    MyPaint now doesn't try to call scons until after --help has been
    processed, so this commit closes #54.

    Nominate version 2.1.0 as the minimum supported level. That's in Ubuntu
    12.04LTS (like, the *old* LTS); also, scons 2.1.0 is required for mingw
    builds, according to https://gna.org/bugs/?21228
    
    The current scons version is 2.3.2 at the time of writing, and that's what
    I mostly develop against.

commit b5d4fed972ba07648e09e68fe600dcff57f08d8e
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-07-18 02:25:48 +0100

    Fix build when using clang on Linux
    
    The build environment was assuming gcc on the "linux2" platform, or at
    least it was using "-z origin" when the linker was being invoked via clang
    wrappers. Replaced with passthru variant for better portability.
    
    We should be testing this to help OSX users and porters (see #49). The
    current way of compiling with a nonstandard compiler is via the standard
    environment vars CC and CXX:
    
       $ CC=clang CXX=clang++ scons
    
    Builds with clang 3.4 and gcc 4.9.0 under Debian testing/unstable.

1	3	SConstruct

commit e7e19240126f44cf93feccb7d1c1c6ada7811030
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-07-16 18:27:15 +0100

    Tidy up brush editor & fix exception
    
    Newer Glade versions insist on writing internal child widgets for scale
    buttons that older GTK and GtkBuilder versions don't support, even when the
    Builder XML file's <requires/> field is set correctly.
    
    Fix the resultant exception by manually deleting the plus_button and
    minus_button internal children of the two (repeated, templated)
    ScaleButtons we use.  We'll just have to be careful about doing that for a
    few versions.
    
    Fixes #46.
    
    Also, a general and long-needed UI tidy-up for the brush editor:
    
    * Symbolic icons for X-axis scale editors (still unintuitive though...)
    * Put the scale editors at the outside & reduce margins a bit
    * Use Gtk.ShadowType.IN for the main edit area - nicer for Ubuntu
    * Silly padding widgets for where we had placeholders (Glade convenience)

commit c8a84143baefc5b58e8ef9dc33e632a909beaf53
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-07-13 03:33:38 +0100

    Forbid zero-pressure events if a button is down
    
    Devices using the Linux evdev driver sometimes report zero pressure for an
    axis when the value hasn't changed since the last reading. This results in
    seemingly random breaks in what should be smooth brushstrokes. This
    behaviour is common with Monoprice, Genius, or other UC-Logic based
    tablets, which typically only have pressure inputs. Tilt inputs suffer from
    this too, for Wacom devices using evdev.
    
    Attempt to fix this by reusing the last good reading for the axes in
    question if a button is held down when we receive a zero reading. For
    pressure this should be fine in all cases. For tilt we may be discarding
    valid readings, but who holds their pen exactly vertical anyway?
    
    This may or may not fix the problem; earlier reports show spurious button
    presses at the times when the pressure hits zero (but it's difficult to
    read someone else's "xinput test" trace!)
    
    This initial attempt at a fix depends on there being no spurious button
    presses or releases at the same time as the input dropping to zero or
    resuming.
    
    Addresses #29, but perhaps not for every tablet (please test!)

45	0	gui/freehand.py

commit dfa897e1340cf119b9f0f163e6e3e58a281c218f
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-07-13 01:01:26 +0100

    Improve debugging some more
    
    Looks like we'll need the source as well to distinguish some multi-faceted
    devices, i.e. tablets sporting touchpads, pad buttons, or eraser pens in
    addition to pen input, all of which which present as separate devices.
    
    Quite a lot of non-Wacom tablets present all of these devices under the
    same name when used with the evdev driver.  See the output people have
    reported in #29.
    
    Getting the references we store right will be important for preferences
    driven inclusion or exclusion of devices, bug #40.

37	24	gui/application.py

commit 0bba3b6a5d7e9a5b721cd0133e73fefa55228cfd
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-07-11 18:19:28 +0100

    More device debugging at startup
    
    * List all axes found
    * Be explicit about devices which get skipped
    * Log a warning if there are no devices with >1 axes
      - Gdk reports all non-"fancy" devices' axes as Gdk.AxisUse.IGNORE now :(
      - Mice and touchpads aren't fancy enough, seemingly
      - Don't know yet if tablets that have problems do this (see #29)
      - Let's find out!

24	0	gui/application.py

commit f42f7437b74aecd9375cb5946a49eadb37ec1953
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-07-10 13:44:27 +0100

    Re-enter current mode when entering fullscreen
    
    When entering fullscreen mode, leave() and then immediately enter() the top
    mode on the stack. This allows modes like freehand to reestablish any hacks
    or workarounds they need which get reset or perturbed by state changes at
    the Gdk window level.
    
    Fixes #39.

7	0	gui/drawwindow.py

commit d789f83052b7c52f5f177b7e7dd20a076b50ba53

    Fix modifiers+space binding
    
    GdkEventKey.is_modifier isn't useful any more in GTK3.12 with introspected
    bindings, so use a more explicit test for modifiers being held down.
    
    Fixes #24

commit 671ca51939f2880f1c9d966021ec0c258c733e3c
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-07-09 18:29:22 +0100

    Support fake, hopefully faster, checkerboard bgs
    
    Optimizing the part of the rendering path involving rendering RGBA data
    with A<1 is proving intractable. "RGBU" (i.e. RGBA with A=1) is noticeably
    faster. Therefore use the tile rendering phase to fake a checkerboard
    background.
    
    New setting: "Prefs → View → Zoom → Use a real checkerboard pattern".
    The faked kind is a little ugly, and is prone to dithering artefacts. Also
    its appearance changes with the mipmap level, which looks odd. Therefore
    it's off by default.
    
    Addresses #21 by trading a little raw performance for hopefully much less
    lag when a fake transparency checkerboard background is turned on. CPU use
    for 1:1 zoom + a single destination-in layer on my system drops from 160%
    to 120%.

1	0	gui/application.py
6	6	gui/drawutils.py
40	9	gui/preferenceswindow.glade
8	0	gui/preferenceswindow.py
50	31	gui/tileddrawwidget.py
69	22	lib/layer.py
1	1	tests/test_rendering.py

commit 27225a349013be933838cc6a2961d7a8e5a26382
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-07-08 13:53:52 +0100

    Forbid Merge Down if either layer is locked
    
    Locking layers should mean that their contents can't be changed, and the
    Merge Down code correctly raises an assertion when it detects this
    condition. However the layers should be greyed out too. Fix the resultant
    exception by indicating in the query that locked layers cannot be sources
    or targets for Merge Down.
    
    Fixes #38.

commit 0b0dad100a3b0d95c11ad8e964cd0160a96c5998
Author: iirelu <totallymyrealemail@hush.ai>
Date:   2014-07-06 04:41:49 +0100

    Simplified the functionality of eraser mode
    
    It now no longer changes size by itself. This is more of the nuclear
    option than anything, as a lot of brushes DO need to have their size
    changed to work well as an eraser, but the previous code was so
    user-hostile and counter-intuitive that it was best to entirely remove
    it.

commit c413a96d7238f0923184f08b6ff4ea6b769e0187
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-07-06 00:36:37 +0100

    Make "Normal" the default mode for groups
    
    The default mode for groups should be Normal rather than Pass-through.
    Pass-through is a bad default for new groups. It's:
    
    * More limiting to the user because its opacity cannot be changed.
    * Not called "Normal", which users might justifiably expect! ☺
    * Not like what GIMP and Krita do.
    
    Fixes #15.

1	1	lib/layer.py

commit 83b0c89784693a81ba8274b3ad1e2b1fffe303cc
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-07-03 01:29:06 +0100

    Work in premult alpha for more modes
    
    Add partial specializations which operate on arrays with premultiplied data
    directly for the following combinations:
    
    * Source Over (for the DSTALPHA=true variant as well)
    * Destination In (both variants)
    * Destination Out (both variants)
    
    Using svg:src-over onto an alpha backdrop within the UI is becoming more
    common (masks, Show Background toggle, Pass-through layer groups).  It
    makes sense to have this code path work more efficiently.
    
    Addresses issue #21 a bit as well: doing this gets a couple of extra fps
    for both the scroll_1x_lazy_all_onscreen_masks and the
    scroll_1x_lazy_all_onscreen_nobg test cases. To me it's noticeable in the
    app too, if still a bit laggy.
    
    Verified we can use the same template for src-over without penalty to the
    no-alpha case, at least on the compiler I use.

59	6	lib/blending.hpp

commit 7b054b01596802f0e051ed67265b27cc301489b6
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-07-05 21:05:17 +0100

    Pixel ops: deparallelize, _c()ify the rgba one
    
    Using OpenMP was the wrong approach for 16→8bit conversion as written. Big
    slowdown, not sure why (false sharing, maybe?); removed. Addresses #21.
    
    Migrate guts of tile_convert_rgba16_to_rgba8() to a private C++-only
    function, to make comparisons with its rgbu sibling simpler.

commit 308c41659cb1cae274601af73221abadcb2132ad
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-07-01 04:04:17 +0100

    display rendering: use a LRU cache
    
    Rendering for the display involves a fix15 → 8bpp transformation after
    generating each fix15 tile. Tile generation is a moderately expensive
    operation compared to conversion, so cache that fix15 data in RAM using a
    cache with an LRU metric.
    
    The ideal maximum capacity for the cache remains to be determined, but 32
    or 64 MiB has a nice feel, and shouldn't cause modern systems any trouble.
    
    Addresses mypaint/mypaint#21.

commit 0de1ace8b1126f02119d8eee7d451203f627ff99
Author: Andrew Chadwick <a.t.chadwick@gmail.com>
Date:   2014-06-30 18:59:36 +0100

    tile clearing: fix HEAVY_DEBUG assertion
    
    Fixes a C++ assertion accidentally introduced in 6414ab0 which was visible
    only when compiled with debug=1.  We use tile_clear() in more
    places now, but its action was data-type specific and calling it with the
    wrong tile array could cause data corruption (hence the assertion)
    
    * Provide separate tile_clear_…() functions for rgba16 and rgba8 data
    * Fixes a potential data corruption with MyPaintSurface.blit_tile_into()
      - was probably never actually provoked in the wild
    
    Minor stuff:
    
    * Headers: remove internal-only …_c() routines from lib/pixops.hpp
    * Couch some assertions in #ifdef HEAVY_DEBUG

    observer to make the error messages a bit more useful.

commit 6d8d00e6721e81b6bb179d48e40bb881de5d47b7
Author: Andrew Chadwick <andrewc-git@piffle.org>
Date:   2014-06-22 16:51:50 +0100

    Save robustness: via tempfile, fsync()ed backup
    
    Addresses https://gna.org/bugs/?19465
    
    Save all files using a tempfile with rename-over if possible to make saving
    on flaky systems which use ext4 a trifle more reliable. At least for newer
    ext4 versions, renaming over an existing file supposedly causes the OS to
    aggressively flush data blocks to disk so that power outages hopefully
    won't lose data.
    
    Also make backup copies (yes, copies), and try to fsync them as we make
    them. This provides an additional safety net, and it makes sense to do an
    fsync for the copy operation at the same time we expect newer ext4
    filesystems to aggressively sync data.
    
    (Why associate the manual fsync with the backup file copyi and not the
    initial write? Well, pretty much any save operation in MyPaint uses
    external libs and filenames.)
    
    If users hate this behaviour, or it takes too long for big files, we can
    reduce the level of paranoia a bit. I guess. I mean, it's not as if fsync()
    actually buys you any safety anyway:
    https://mail.zope.org/pipermail/zodb-dev/2004-July/007689.html

6	7	lib/document.py
76	0	lib/fileutils.py
5	3	lib/layer.py

    * Tarballs have git revision info baked into them
    * Builds with no .git use baked-in release info if present
    * Document new versioning & release strategy
      - now use Semantic Versioning
      - prerelease tarball verions will compare correctly
      - version always suffixed by (potential) prerelease during development
      - only the final release commit is unsuffixed
    * Slightly meaningless version bump to 1.1.1-alpha
      - this really means the same thing as "git after 1.1.0", same as now
      - its betas & release will probably be 1.2.0, given the amount of change
      - it has to be semantically after 1.1.0 :)

commit d8be065b7e604064edb0fc274c42b2c7c40ab313
Author: Andrew Chadwick <andrewc-git@piffle.org>
Date:   2014-06-17 20:10:34 +0100

    Layers stack: add Pass-through mode
    
    Re-express the absence of group isolation as a mode in its own right, to
    simplify the user interface. This replaces the toggle for group isolation,
    which was making the UI messy and hard to grok.
    
    * New mode: "Pass-through", for layer groups only
      - named after the one in a certain large photo manipulation package
      - should be fairly self explanatory
      - hides lots of pointless internal complexity, yay!
    * Remove isolated flag and group auto-isolation test (much rejoicing)
    * Move UI strings to lib.layer
    * Pass-through mode prevents the opacity being set, so grey out UI bits
    * Update doctests
    * SetLayerMode command now also saves & restores previous opacity
    * Remove the update() mechanism for SetLayerMode
      - the update is no longer atomic, so it's trickier to code now
      - update() was dubious anyway: users may want to compare back'n'forth
    * Mark a few internal constants with underscore prefixes

commit d1fb5cfdd13e61c0b36e0d822e2dec2b5e40cc83
Author: Andrew Chadwick <andrewc-git@piffle.org>
Date:   2014-06-16 01:14:49 +0100

    Add a GtkAccelMap editor
    
    The ability to rebind the global accelmap directly from the menus is gone
    permanently in GTK 3.12+, which prefers that you migrate to GtkApplication
    and manage your accelerators through its API.  However due to API
    mismatches, binding editors working via GtkApplication cannot be
    implemented simply AND completely AND in a way that's compatible with 3.10.
    
    We'd like to target 3.10 while not having accels break in 3.12+.  Something
    has to change.  Sorry, Martin ☹
    
    For now, add an editor for the legacy global AccelMap to the dialog so that
    accels can be edited under both GTK+ 3.10 and 3.12+. The UI we'll need for
    this after migrating to GtkApplication will be pretty similar to this old
    GtkAction stuff, so it's hopefully not a wasted effort.
    
    https://gna.org/bugs/?21751

16	0	glade/mypaint_widgets.xml
424	0	gui/accelmap.py
0	8	gui/main.py
55	58	gui/preferenceswindow.glade
1	0	gui/preferenceswindow.py

commit 4bf025fb2fc72ef792f8a4dfb6bd3647fffdba37
Author: Andrew Chadwick <andrewc-git@piffle.org>
Date:   2014-06-13 17:12:15 +0100

    UI: better behaviour when no layer is selected
    
    Bit of a grab-bag: basically make it all work correctly when the layer
    stack is empty (currently that's just for debugging purposes). Helps shed
    light on some weird edge cases.
    
    * Actions which require a current layer now have managed sensitivities
    * Add Layer can now add if there's nothing in the stack
    * Make certain GtkTreeView state-management callbacks more robust
    * Layer mode combo now has its sensitivity managed
    * Layer opacity scale now has its sensitivity managed
    * More careful checking when updating the UI selection
    * More careful auto-scrolling when the stack presents as empty
    * Clear current path when clearing the root stack
    * Bugfix: announce path clearing done by set_current_path() (missed one)
    * API clarity: rename command methods if they only affect current layer
    * Robustness: such actions and commands now stop if current layer invalid

commit c537a4f3c6951bba22e01396e0f6265deec57801
Author: Andrew Chadwick <andrewc-git@piffle.org>
Date:   2014-06-13 16:37:29 +0100

    debugging: add flag for testing layer notify bugs
    
    The GUI code *should* be capable of displaying an empty layers list now,
    but it isn't. Not being able to do so reliably really hides certain bugs
    when you're trying to work with someone debugging their problem via bug
    report discussions.
    
    Add a debugging flag (off by default, non-user-accessible) to lib.document
    allowing the document model's New, Load, and Clear options to create empty
    layer stacks. That should help in eliminating edge cases.
